items.html: Health care organization across the country have grappled with rising violence for several years, but the local impact is rarely well known or understood. As reports of violence from our own staff increased, we began seeking ways to amplify their stories.
items.message:
Fix any of the following:
  Some page content is not contained by landmarks

items.html: The response from our frontline caregivers was immediate, with individuals coming forward to share heartbreaking stories.

items.html: We chose to raise our voices, so we can end the silence on health care violence, support each other and work toward solutions together.

items.html: <html lang="en" dir="ltr" prefix="content: http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/  dc: http://purl.org/dc/terms/  foaf: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/  og: http://ogp.me/ns#  rdfs: http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#  schema: http://schema.org/  sioc: http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#  sioct: http://rdfs.org/sioc/types#  skos: http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#  xsd: http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema# " class="crjs js" style="height: 100%;">
<body class="page--node-30307 site--global v4master inner_page path-node page-node-type-landing-page page guest" style="position: relative; min-height: 100%; top: 0px;">
<div class="gdpr-alert fixed-banner-privacy alert" role="alert" style="display: block;">
End the silence on health care violence.
Across the country, health care staff suffer more violent assaults than any other profession.
Our staff share their stories, as a national crisis hits home.
As featured in the New York Times
Health care staff are 5x times more likely to suffer a workplace violence injury.
Health care staff are 5x times more likely to suffer a workplace violence injury.

75%
of health care staff say they have experienced violence in the past year

85%
of physicians believe violence has gotten worse in the past 5 years

Julie Vieth
Emergency Medicine Medical Director
"Hospitals cannot solve this problem alone. It takes all of us working together, thinking differently..."
Play Video

Laura Mulvey
Physician
Laura got into emergency medicine to help people, not watch as her colleague was attacked by a patient wielding kitchen shears
Play Video

Ali Abdulkadir
Clinical Patient Safety Attendant
Abdul loves to care for people, even though he knows it could mean a punch to the chest.
Play Video

Alex Dees
Technician
Like Alex, many health care staff experience lasting trauma from workplace violence.
Play Video

Amal Hussein
Clinical Patient Safety Attendant
Violence isnt always physical, something Amal knows all too well.
Play Video

Matt Looft
Charge Nurse
As a nurse in the emergency department, Matt cares for people during the hardest moments in their lives. One of them knocked him unconscious.
Play Video

About UVM Health Network
Across the country, health care staff suffer more violent assaults than any other profession.
Our staff share their stories, as a national crisis hits home.

Sunil Eappen, MD, MBA
President and CEO, The University of Vermont Health Network
As featured in the New York Times
This project was featured by The New York Times. Editors of the news organization selected our video to be part of the national discussion on topics of importance on their video opinion page.

26%
of health care staff have considered leaving their job because of workplace violence

75%
of health care staff say they have experienced violence in the past year

85%
of physicians believe violence has gotten worse in the past 5 years

Julie Vieth
Emergency Medicine Medical Director
Hospitals cannot solve this problem alone. It takes all of us working together, thinking differently
Play Video

Laura Mulvey
Physician
Laura got into emergency medicine to help people, not watch as her colleague was attacked by a patient wielding kitchen shears
Play Video

Ali Abdulkadir
Clinical Patient Safety Attendant
Abdul loves to care for people, even though he knows it could mean a punch to the chest.
Play Video

Alex Dees
Technician
Like Alex, many health care staff experience lasting trauma from workplace violence.
Play Video

Amal Hussein
Clinical Patient Safety Attendant
Violence isnt always physical, something Amal knows all too well.
Play Video

Matt Looft
Charge Nurse
As a nurse in the emergency department, Matt cares for people during the hardest moments in their lives. One of them knocked him unconscious.
Play Video

Health care organization across the country have grappled with rising violence for several years, but the local impact is rarely well known or understood. As reports of violence from our own staff increased, we began seeking ways to amplify their stories.
The response from our frontline caregivers was immediate, with individuals coming forward to share heartbreaking stories.
We chose to raise our voices, so we can end the silence on health care violence, support each other and work toward solutions together.
end the silence on health care violence
Number and rate of nonfatal work injuries in detailed private industries.

This project was featured by The New York Times. Editors of the news organization selected our video to be part of the national discussion on topics of importance on their video opinion page.

<a aria-label="" class="" data-entity-substitution="" data-entity-type="" data-entity-uuid="" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/24/opinion/emergency-room-hospitals-violence.html" id="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" title="">
Health care staff are 5x times more likely to suffer a workplace violence injury.
Health care staff are 5x times more likely to suffer a workplace violence injury.
Health care staff are 5x times more likely to suffer a workplace violence injury.

26%
of health care staff have considered leaving their job because of workplace violence

26%
of health care staff have considered leaving their job because of workplace violence

75%
of health care staff say they have experienced violence in the past year

85%
of physicians believe violence has gotten worse in the past 5 years

Julie Vieth
Emergency Medicine Medical Director
"Hospitals cannot solve this problem alone. It takes all of us working together, thinking differently..."
Hospitals cannot solve this problem alone. It takes all of us working together, thinking differently
Play Video
Play Video

Laura Mulvey
Physician
Laura got into emergency medicine to help people, not watch as her colleague was attacked by a patient wielding kitchen shears
Play Video
Play Video

Ali Abdulkadir
Clinical Patient Safety Attendant
Abdul loves to care for people, even though he knows it could mean a punch to the chest.
Play Video
Play Video

Alex Dees
Technician
Like Alex, many health care staff experience lasting trauma from workplace violence.
Play Video
Play Video

Amal Hussein
Clinical Patient Safety Attendant
Violence isnt always physical, something Amal knows all too well.
Play Video
Play Video

Matt Looft
Charge Nurse
As a nurse in the emergency department, Matt cares for people during the hardest moments in their lives. One of them knocked him unconscious.
